node.title: How to get the volume of mesh?
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I am trying to output the volume information about the mesh I used. I found some useful example in https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/auxkernels/VolumeAux.html.
I run the example and got the result below:
This was the mesh of the problem:

This was the volume output of the problem:

I am a little confused since I thought the output volume didn't match the real situation.
I went to the source code and found the volume was calculated using return _bnd ? _current_side_volume : _current_elem_volume;. I thought it should calculate the volume of the mesh. I might misunderstood something and perhaps there were some problems with my output method. I am wondering if anyone can get me some suggestions on getting the volume of the mesh. I should use this value as a parameter in developing my own application.
Thank you so much for your help.

Hello
So you want the volume of the mesh, not each cell in the mesh?
if so, you may use this postprocessor
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/postprocessors/VolumePostprocessor.html
Guillaume

I want each cell volume. Sorry about the mistake.
Huihua
then VolumeAux is the way. Is the result wrong? What is the problem?

I thought the result should provide 20 volume values since there were 20 cells. But the output only showed 6 different color bars and the values didn't match the manually calculated ones.
For example, the left down corner cell should have a volume around 0.4875 based on the mesh information calculation (1.5/2*1.3/2=0.4875). However, the light blue (left down corner cell) showed a value around 0.4125.

ah yes that is weird indeed!
Could you please paste your input file syntax for the VolumeAux ?

Sure. Actually it was an example shown in the link https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/auxkernels/VolumeAux.html.
Below is the detail:
[Mesh]
  [cmg]
    type = CartesianMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    dx = '1.5 2.4 0.1'
    dy = '1.3 0.9'
    ix = '2 1 1'
    iy = '2 3'
  []
[]

[AuxVariables/volume]
  order = CONSTANT
  family = MONOMIAL
[]

[AuxKernels/volume_aux]
  type = VolumeAux
  variable = volume
[]

[Problem]
  solve = false
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Steady
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  csv = true
[]

The total output showed 5 different color bars and that were correct since there were 5 different volumes for this problem. Sorry about the misunderstood before.
The only porblem now was the exact value of the volume seemed didn't match the manually calculated ones.

It matches on my machine?
For some of the areas for example, I get
0.4875 in the bottom left, 1.56 in the bottom middle/right and 0.03 for the top right.
now analytically we should have:
1.5/2 * 1.3/2 = 0.4875
2.4/1 * 1.3/2 = 1.56
0.1/1 * 0.9/3 = 0.03

Yes. But the color bar value showing that the bottom left should be 0.4125 while the calculated one was 0.4875. The green one from color bar was 0.795 while the calculated one should be 0.72.
Wait, is there any different with the color? like light green and dark green? I thought the color bar with values on side should be the indicating values of the volume. Can I use another output method to print out the real value instead of the color bar figure?

in paraview you may hover over the cells and get the values
I dont know about peacock

So this VolumeAux can get the cell volume well. Right?
Besides, I can use paraview, but I couldn't see the values when I hover the cells. Could you please tell me which version you used?

You can also run mesh only mode (--mesh-only on command line) to get some output like this:
<cut>

  Mesh Subdomains:
   Subdomain 0: 16 elems (QUAD4, 16 active), 25 active nodes
    Volume: 1
    Bounding box minimum: (x,y,z)=(       0,        0,        0)
    Bounding box maximum: (x,y,z)=(       1,        1,        0)
    Bounding box delta: (x,y,z)=(       1,        1,        0)
   Global mesh volume = 1

where it will show the volume of each subdomain and the total volume.
OK. Thank you so much for that information. I will have a try.

node.title: Solve not converging when called through surrogate trainer.
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I am exploring the functionality built into MOOSE for building surrogate models. I am playing around with a very simple example of a heat sink conducting into air. When I run the input file on its own the solver converges fine however when I then go to train my nearest point surrogate I am getting lots of errors about the solve failing to converge. I think this maybe because my sample is not being parsed through correct?

 radiator_steady.i 

[Mesh]
  [file]
    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = 'radiator_smaller.msh'
  []
[]

[Variables]
    [T]
    []
[]

[ICs]
  [radiator_ic]
    type = ConstantIC
    variable = T
    value = 373.15
    block = 'inner_surface'
  []
  [air_ic]
    type = ConstantIC
    variable = T
    value = 283.15
    block = 'outer_surface'
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [hc]
    type = ADHeatConduction
    variable = T
  []
[]

[Materials]
    [radiator]
        type = ADHeatConductionMaterial
        thermal_conductivity = 386
        specific_heat = 389
        block = 'inner_surface'
    []
    [radiator_density]
        type = ADGenericConstantMaterial
        prop_names = 'density'
        prop_values = 8960
        block = 'inner_surface'
    []
    [air]
        type = ADHeatConductionMaterial
        thermal_conductivity = 0.025
        specific_heat = 1000
        block = 'outer_surface'
    []
    [air_density]
        type = ADGenericConstantMaterial
        prop_names = 'density'
        prop_values = 1.2754
        block = 'outer_surface'
    []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [smp]
    type = SMP
    full = false
  []
[]

[Executioner]
    automatic_scaling = true
    line_search = 'default'
    type = Steady
    solve_type = 'NEWTON'
    petsc_options_iname='-pc_type'
    petsc_options_value='lu'
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [T_avg]
    type = AverageNodalVariableValue
    variable = T
  []
[]

[Outputs]
[]



 nearest_point_training.i 

[StochasticTools]
[]

[Distributions]
    [rad_k]
        type = Uniform
        lower_bound = 300
        upper_bound = 500
    []
    [rad_h]
        type = Uniform
        lower_bound = 300
        upper_bound = 500
    []
[]

[Samplers]
    [sample]
        type = LatinHypercube
        distributions = 'rad_k rad_h'
        num_rows = 100
        execute_on = PRE_MULTIAPP_SETUP
    []
[]

[MultiApps]
    [sub]
      type = SamplerFullSolveMultiApp
      input_files = radiator_steady.i
      sampler = sample
    []
  []
  
  [Controls]
    [cmdline]
      type = MultiAppSamplerControl
      multi_app = sub
      sampler = sample
      param_names = 'Materials/radiator/thermal_conductivity Materials/radiator/specific_heat'
    []
  []

  [Transfers]
    [data]
      type = SamplerReporterTransfer
      from_multi_app = sub
      sampler = sample
      stochastic_reporter = results
      from_reporter = 'T_avg/value'
    []
  []
  
  [Reporters]
    [results]
      type = StochasticReporter
      outputs = none
    []
  []

  [Trainers]
    [nearest_point_avg]
      type = NearestPointTrainer
      execute_on = timestep_end
      sampler = sample
      response = results/data:T_avg:value
    []
  []

  [Outputs]
    [out]
      type = SurrogateTrainerOutput
      trainers = 'nearest_point_avg'
      execute_on = FINAL
    []
  []


Thanks in advance!

Hi,
Your inputs look fine to me. What exactly is the error you are getting? Is the radiator_steady.i solve not converging? One thing to try is to check if the solve converges with the bounds of your distributions. For instance, setting Materials/radiator/thermal_conductivity=500. This will tell you if your physics is having a difficult time converging.
I'd be happy to try it out myself, but I will need the mesh file you have.
Zach

node.title: Thermal Hydraulics: FlowChannel1Phase Oreintated at an angle?
node.bodyText:
Hi MOOSE team, I am currently trying to use the thermal hydraulics module to simplify some fluids problems. I was wondering if there is any way to use 1D flow channels (specifically FlowChannel1Phase) that are at an angle or incline, as shown in the piece of art I have attached. If I try and change the orientation vector I get a reminder that these components should be aligned with one of the axes. It may be that there is no way round this currently. If so, is there any chance it will be added in future? Many thanks for any help.

)
@licharlot
There is no general restriction on the flow channels orientation. How are you connecting your pipes together?Are they coupled to a heat structure? Are you using any user objects like LayeredAverage?

Ahhh thank you! They are coupled to a heat structure, I've been using HeatStructureFromFile3D and HeatTransferFromHeatStructure3D1Phase. I can see the restriction is on this side of things, as mentioned in the HeatTransferFromHeatStructure3D1Phase syntax documentation. I assume one way around this could be to manually set the gravity vector to change the frame of reference, is there a simpler way around this that I should be aware of?

Yes there is that restriction for the 3D heat structure. I think adjusting the gravity vector for each flow channel is the best way at this point. You won't have that restriction if you use 2D heat structures (cylindrical or plate).

node.title: Axisymmetric model creation in 3D
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
As part of my recent work concerning radiation damage models, i am interested in creating a 3D cylindrical pipe model (see below) that mainly simulate elasticity effects. The damage resulting from irradiation induced swelling is then captured through the thermal strains calculated from ComputeThermalExpansionEigenstrain.

I am currently looking at a suitable 3D axisymmetric model from the repository that will form the basis for my model. As far as i checked most of them were reduced 2D models with coord_type set to RZ. I wonder how would this command look like if i want to use a 3D model. I am aware a 2D model would suffice for most of the cases, unless if one want to address problems relating to stress effects in the vicinity of the circumference e.g., torsion. My intention here is to compare with analytical results for which a 3D FE model would result in a better comparision.
Kind regards,
Arun

Hello
We currently do not have a mesh generator that will extrude a 2D RZ geometry to a 3D model.
Is your geometry extruded in the axial direction? I see to see a bend at the top and at the bottom of this picture.
You can use free meshing software gmsh or cubit-learn to generate this mesh it does not seem too complicated.
Guillaume

Well, the issue is not about meshing, but how do we make use of this 3D mesh and run an axi-symmetric model. Below here is my mesh done in cubit and ready to go in to simulation. My concern here is what should be set to this parameter coord_type when we want to run this simulation with a cylindrical coordinate system and problem dimensionality as 3. Will RZ work even for this case?

if you have a 3D mesh then you should run XYZ coordinates.
We do not have RthetaZ in MOOSE, only RZ

Yes that's fine. I have gases flowing inside the pipe and so wanted to apply gas pressure in the inner walls. I am wondering how to intertpret radial direction working from within the cartesian system.

The radial direction is not treated any particular way in the cartesian solve.
Are your kernels or your material properties dependent on r ?

As said earlier, my boundary condition for gas pressure depends on the radial direction R. If i work in cartesian system and choose one of the axes for applying this pressure BC, i will be applying in the wrong direction. Either i would need to choose cylindrical system, which for this 3D case is not possible or i may need to revert to a 2D model.
You will have to apply the BC on both X and Y axis, with a projection based on the local angle.
This seems a quite different way. How do one can calculate the local angle and where this would be accounted in the boundary conditions?
I think you may want to look at Pressure.C in the tensor mechanics module src/bcs folder. It uses the normal to compute the contribution of the external pressure to the residual on the bc

At least for small deformations, I suppose you can use the local normal
vector to resolve the normal pressure into x and y components (requires a
little bit of coordinate transformation). You might have to write code for
it.
…

 and where this would be accounted in the boundary conditions?

Any ideas/suggestions here would help me to solve this issue and focus next on integrating these transformed corrdinates in to the pressure BC application module swiftly.

You should not need the local angle, moose. Boundary normals should be
accessible easily _normals[_qp]

With the normals, i am wondering how to calculate the angle theta needed for coordinate conversion as stated here.

You might probably thinking about a different way to solve this problem

You can do it your way and calculating the angle should be trivial right ?
n.x = mag(n)*max(x)* cos(theta), where n is the normal vector and x is the
unit x vector. I think the normals in moose are unit magnitude and so is
the unit vector in x. So the angle to x axis would simply be cos-1(x
component of the normal vector).
In a more general sense, with this procedure, you should be able to apply
an arbitrary normal pressure on any arbitrary plane. The only tricky part
might be to add residuals to the individual components in moose, but you
can use an action to do this i think.

 You are receiving this because you commented.Message ID:
 ***@***.***>

Thanks Srinath for the inputs. With this conversion based approach, theta eventually can be calculated as a inverse cosine of x component of the normal vector. I am now looking for a suitable template to start my developments. I would like to ask if its more relevant to copy the class Pressure that applies pressure on boundaries?

I think you should look at pressure action and just modify the scaling
factors to the correct values. Just saying if pressure was a scalar then
p*n is the vector so the components of the vector give you the relevant
values in each direction.
…
On Thu, Jun 23, 2022, 2:13 PM abarun22 ***@***.***> wrote:
 Thanks Srinath for the inputs. With this conversion based approach, theta
 eventually can be calculated as a inverse cosine of x component of the
 normal vector. I am now looking for a suitable template to start my
 developments. I would like to ask if its more relevant to copy the class
 Pressure that applies pressure on boundaries?

 Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
 <#21366 (reply in thread)>,
 or unsubscribe
 <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ACYC6LLMG7FWMAJPW5NHDXLVQSSM5ANCNFSM5ZME7ZEQ>

 You are receiving this because you commented.Message ID:
 ***@***.***>

I guess this has already been implemented in Pressure.C. Here is the computeQpResidual function from this file that will tell you how the pressure value is resolved in to component directions. I do not know what _test does in this case, but this block would for sure apply the pressure in the normal direction on any given surface, which is what we need and this should work correctly without going for actual conversion to cylindrical coordinate systems.
Real
Pressure::computeQpResidual()
{
  return computeFactor() * (_normals[_qp](_component) * _test[_i][_qp]);
}

Probably you might want to say something like this:
[BCs]
  [./Pressure]
    [./pbc]
      boundary = 'inner'
      factor= 50
      displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
    [../]
  [../]
[]

Here the x & y displacements are given just to specify that the first two resolved components of pressure are meant to be applied on to this boundary 'inner'. This is what i thought based on our earlier discussions, probably you could pour in your suggestions.
Kind regards,
Arun

Yes this is all you need would be my guess. This is a relatively new addition, since in the previous avatar of Pressure BC, we needed to specify a component, see ADPressure.C for the AD version of the old Pressure.C. I can see now it is deprecated and also very recently (in the last 2 days). So all you need to specify is the pressure value for each of your x and y directions and this should do the rest. The _test is necessary from the weak form of the bc. You can easily verify that the correct pressure is being applied by validating with the axisymmetric 2d model and a cross-section in your 3d model.
Hi Srinath, FYI, the new pressure BC works fine with the results comparing ok with the equivalent analytical results. Thanks for the suggestions.

node.title: Free format Fortran UMAT
node.bodyText:
Hello,
when running make to compile my UMAT I get
Can't open included file 'xxx.f90'
Does that mean that MOOSE does not support free format UMATs?
@Flolaffel have you tried passing the compiler flag -ffree-form?
I'm not sure, what you mean by using -ffree-form. To me it seems like that's not an available option when using the make command. What are you refering to?

You can add additional compiling and linking flags by modifying the environment variables.
You may also modify the Makefile used to compile the UMAT

FWIW it looks like there's a Makefile variable PLUGIN_FLAGS that you can set to influence how your UMAT gets compiled. I set this in my app's Makefile to change the line length etc. You can see what else goes into building UMAT plugins here.

Update: I have to admit I don't have enough knowledge about UMATs, Fortran and compiler flags to solve this problem on my own. The UMAT I'm working with is written (not by me) in a mix of F77 and F90. From @jessecarterMOOSE's comment I saw that MOOSE provides options to compile F90. However in my case make always exited with an error when it came to compile the F90 part of the UMAT. So I went and asked my master thesis supervisor for help.
Here is how he solved it: He used @GiudGiud's recommended make -n  command to get get the flags MOOSE uses for compiling. Then, following those commands, he wrote a script that creates the .plugin file you need for MOOSE externally. You can then simply copy that file into the MOOSE plugins folder and it seems to work just fine.

node.title: [Userobjects]
node.bodyText:
Dear users,
I am trying to calculate a value by using Userobjects.
Initial guessing of value A -> Use A to calculate quadrature point values -> Sum up all the values on a plane (or surface) -> If this value is not meet with some criteria, do it again by changing value A -> ... ->Until satisfy the criteria.
Are there any Userobjects to support this method? or any other ways?
Best regards,

Hello
How often you trying to perform these iterations? Is this one iteration per time step or are you trying to converge the process every time step (or more often, every nonlinear/linear iteration) ?
Is A a field or a single floating point value?
Guillaume

Dear Guillaume,
I just have to perform this calculation once per time step at timestep_begin.
A should be a single floating value, it doesn't have to be a field value.
Best regards,
Nakkyu

I think the easiest setup will be to place this A calculation in a MultiApp.
This multiapp will run a fake transient to determine A.
You will want to use this
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/postprocessors/SideAverageValue.html
to compute the value on the plane (add a sideset for the plane).
then you will want to use the control system to modify the value of A at each iteration:
this is the base one you could use
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/controls/RealFunctionControl.html
but I tend to think you may want to use this one instead, which I wrote
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/controls/PIDTransientControl.html

Thank you very much Guillaume.
I will give it a try!

no this isnt going to work.
The postprocessors are part of a loop over all elements, which is in the internals of moose (the loops are in include/loops).
What you did is not executing the postprocessor over the entire mesh several times, only over a single element
You need to decompose operations, and use a different object for each part of the process

Thank you for your comment!
As following your comments, multiapp + postprocessor works.
Now I am trying to make an executioner file that can terminate the calculation of value A!
Thank you very much!

ok so to do that you may use a Terminator and store the A value as a postprocessor
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/userobject/Terminator.html

Yes, thanks a lot! I found a terminator and modify it to finish the calculation between -1 < A < 1, and it works very well!
Cheers,
nakkyu

node.title: Input different elasticity tensor Cijkl in tensor_mechanics
node.bodyText:
Hello,
We decided to calculate elastic properties of multiphase polycrystals using tensor_mechanics module.
I found from test examples that Cijkl for single phase polycrystal could be input within Materials object as followed:
  [./elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeElasticityTensorCP
    C_ijkl = '1.684e5 1.214e5 1.214e5 1.684e5 1.214e5 1.684e5 0.754e5 0.754e5 0.754e5'
    fill_method = symmetric9
    read_prop_user_object = prop_read
  [../]

I'm wondering there's a way that I could input different C_ijkls for different phases or elements? Similar to what we did to input different euler angles. Thanks.
[UserObjects]
  [./prop_read]
    type = PropertyReadFile
    prop_file_name = 'euler_ang_file.txt'
    # Enter file data as prop#1, prop#2, .., prop#nprop
    nprop = 3
    read_type = block
    nblock= 2
  [../]
[]

Hello
It would not be very hard to do but it's not present in the current code afaik. You can inspire yourself from the treatment of the euler angle with a PropertyReadFile.
I ll let others comment on what spatial granularity is appropriate for the stiffness tensor.
Guillaume

node.title: MOOSE memory requirement is too high
node.bodyText:
Hi, MOOSE experts.
I want to calculate a case with a lot of variables. It has 46,800 elements, 17 variables and 570,000 degrees of freedom.

I used the lu method and the petsc settings are as follows:
  petsc_options = '-snes_converged_reason -ksp_converged_reason -snes_linesearch_monitor'
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_shift_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu       NONZERO'
  line_search = 'none'

But when I run it on a computer with 64GB of RAM, the RAM is full and no results are produced. I think that the memory occupied by MOOSE may be too large, and it is not feasible to deal with some large-scale problems. Or is there some problem with my PETSc setup. I have tried ilu but the results do not converge, and only when using lu (maybe set to other options will also converge). Can you give me some advice on saving memory and guaranteeing convergence?

What is your solve_type in Executioner input block? Its default value is PJFNK. Can you turn on Debug/show_actions=true on command-line so that we can know for sure the memory is due to LU (probably the case). That command-line option prints the memory usage at every setup stage. Did you try any other pc types like
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'hypre boomeramg'

Note the preconditioning type is problem dependent. I know nothing about your physics.

Now that it looks reasonable, is there any solution for me. Because the problem of 47,000 grids is really small. But 64GB of memory can no longer meet its needs.

The easiest solution would be for you to find a larger machine to run the case on. Do you have access to a university cluster?
The harder solution would be for you to find a cheaper preconditioner for your physics. You will want to look at these pages:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Preconditioning/index.html
and create a custom split

I think the first method is more feasible. I would also like to ask, when you use MOOSE to calculate large projects, such as the problem of 5 million grids, do you increase the memory or solve the problem by finding a cheaper preconditioner? If the problem of 17 variables and 50,000 grids already requires 64GB of memory, wouldn't the problem of 5 million grids require 7TB of memory? This is obviously not realistic. LU is the most memory-intensive algorithm. Do you have any other algorithm recommendations to save memory and ensure convergence?

We usually find a cheaper preconditioner.
For fluids like you are doing you could code up a linearized segregated scheme like SIMPLE
OK, thank you for your suggestions. You're very helpful.

LU is the most expensive one pretty much.
You can try saving some amount of memory by using distributed meshes. But the big one is likely the preconditioner here

node.title: Compilation Problem FC36 & GCC 12.1.1

node.bodyText:
Unfortunately we do not typically test major versioned compilers that are a year or two old, let alone one month old 😆
If you need to use GCC 12.1, we would happily accept a PR for this

Hello
It seems this is a compiler warning that gets treated as an error to me. We can fix this pretty easily. Thanks for reporting it! If you dont get to it first we'll ping back here when it's fixed
Guillaume

Hello
We have fixed the error (really a compiler warning treated as an error out of caution).
There are still other warnings, mostly coming from Eigen which we will address in the near future, on the libmesh side.
The update is currently in next/ and should be propagated to devel and master once we have fixed other conflicting PRs.
Please let us know if you are still hitting any issue with building with gcc-12.
Guillaume

node.title: 3D Berkovich Indentation Example Units
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am having trouble establishing the units used for the example in:
moose/modules/contact/examples/3d_berkovich/
The journal file used to create the mesh does not specify units and neither does the input file itself. The mesh displaces at the same rate as time ending at 1.8. Units in finite element analysis are arbitrary, however, given the examples inputs there must be units associated with the displacement and time. I am assuming seconds and micrometers. Is there something I am missing, is there any way to confirm this?

Hello
There is documentation for this example
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/contact/BerkovichIndenterNodeFace.html
does it help with the units? Seems time is in seconds.
Guillaume

Thank you for the quick reply, this does confirm time is in seconds. I was not able to gleam other units from this documentation or the nearby 2d examples when searching earlier.
edit: it does note that the parameters for the material are arbitrary, however, I don't think this means that the length scale is too.
I think you should be able to determine whether it's in m, mm or micrometer from your knowledge of the problem and the material properties a this point.
Given the stress output by running the simulation, it would make sense that the units are micrometers. Thank you for the help.
If I recall correctly, the length unit is micro meter and the stress is mpa.
